triples.name: Microbiome
triples.relevance: The paper analyzes soil microbiomes under environmental stress to understand how communities respond to stress.

triples.name: Network analysis
triples.relevance: The paper uses network analysis to assess microbial community structure and identify network properties like modularity.

triples.name: Ecosystem services
triples.relevance: The paper focuses on how microbiome destabilization could undermine ecosystem services provided by microbial communities.

triples.name: Biodiversity
triples.relevance: The paper measures changes in prokaryotic and fungal diversity as a key response to environmental stress.

triples.name: Modularity (networks)
triples.relevance: The paper identifies modularity as a key network property that declines with environmental stress.

triples.name: Ecological stability
triples.relevance: The paper provides novel evidence that environmental stress destabilizes microbial networks, directly addressing ecosystem stability.

triples.name: Abiotic stress
triples.relevance: The paper examines how abiotic environmental stressors (elevation/water availability) affect microbial community properties.

triples.name: Soil microbiology
triples.relevance: The paper studies soil microbes and their network properties in response to environmental gradients.

triples.name: Stress gradient hypothesis
triples.relevance: The paper applies the stress gradient hypothesis to explain shifts in negative:positive biotic interactions under stress.

triples.name: Community structure
triples.relevance: The paper proposes that environmental stress alters microbial community structure by changing compartmentalization and association patterns.
